Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2011 11:39AM banjobanjo wrote: Why not just a bland sentence about continuing your treatment plan?  Just give your grandfather a sentence that is innocuous if you don't want to give details, and people will just pass quickly over it when they read the letter. I'm just sending cards this year - in the last six months, my husband had a silent heart attack, which was found luckily on a normal medical ECG.  When he went into hospital for a heart catheter procedure to find out what the blockage was, I drove home (Germany) to find that my father had died in England an hour before. I managed four days in England to help my mother with all the bureaucracy, then back to Germany for my husband's triple bypass operation, then back to England for the cremation.  After looking after my husband through his recovery, he was one day away from being fully signed off by his cardiologist as fit and that was the day I was diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer with spine and brain mets.  All this in six months - I'm not putting that out in other people's Christmases.  The ones who need to know, know.  The rest will just get cards - I don't want them to know.  Merry Christmas, whatever your solution! Barbara

Posts.Content: May 9, 2012 02:39PM banjobanjo wrote: I see your point - sharing your diagnosis with people can be beneficial in making them more body-aware and careful and also shows them a role model of how to live with and cope with a serious illness.  It also makes life easier not to have to cover things up.  I also understand completely the reasons why you are protecting your little ones.  I am completely shocked, however, at some of the reactions you speak about - why on earth would someone want you out of your house because you have cancer?   To be honest, I think you should just leave things as they are - concentrate on your new home and when you get to know new friends and neighbours maybe there will be some you feel able to talk to.  I chose not to tell anyone except one trusted neighbour because I didn't want people bothering me with questions all the time or pitying me.  This has worked very well.  I also retired from my job with 'vertebral damage' (spinal mets) - a few ex-colleagues know but the news didn't go round like wildfire and I left without being the object of dramatic sadness and emotion.  I think you need to leave this negativity behind and look ahead to your new community with excitement.  The friends that left you were not friends. Wishing you luck in your new home.

Posts.Content: banjobanjo wrote: Just thought I could give some positive news to those people doing WBR. I finished WBR in November 2011 and had brain scan today.  Out of 20 mets, 19 have vanished; only one speck remains (from the biggest met that had some oedema).  My husband and I were so anxious as I had had dizziness and nausea and pain/pressure in my ear with colourless fluid coming out.  The scan showed that the fluid is coming from the petrus, i.e. an inner ear infection and that was probably bothering my balance.  The doctor was grinning with pleasure to be able to show me such a good scan, although being his usual cautious self, he did remind me that it wasn't a cure, that there would be a recurrence at some time in the future, possibly in six months, but that the WBR had been very successful. Off to the ear doctor now for some more antibiotics and then, I think, a nap for both of us stressed-out people. Hoping anyone else out there doing WBR has a good response too.  Barbara 'And we are here as on a darkling plain, swept with confused alarms of struggle and flight, where ignorant armies clash by night. Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2011 12:41AM banjobanjo wrote: Well said, Zoh!  We love reading your posts.   I made a small but important decision the other day - I decided to put a watershed on cancer talk between me and my husband (and any family, friend, guest who might be at our home in the evening).  I decided that we can discuss anything at all involving my treatment, etc until 8 p.m. but after that the subject is banned because I don't want it lingering into my evening mood and consequently bedtime.  I now have very good tranquilisers which are give me sleep and I wake feeling refreshed and clear-headed and ready for the day but I won't put up with the down mood from talking about cancer in the evening.  During the day, all is open for discussion.  It's working well. Hope you all have a good day today, Barbara

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2012 12:42PM - edited Apr 25, 2012 12:42PM by banjobanjo Hi Laurie, I can identify with what you say.  My best days are when I'm distracted; the ones when I brood tend to pull me towards the dark.  As for God, I have tried all my life to speak to him but there's been nobody there.  I laugh with my friends but they and I know about the shadow behind the laugh.  Basically, I feel I am plodding along to my end, no blaze of glory, no great travel 'must-dos' (in fact, when I was sick at the weekend, I realised there wasn't anywhere in the world I wanted to be except in my own bed).  So, being now without a job (thank you, cancer) I work at my hobby and make quilts.  Seems such a quiet, pathetic way to live what's left of my life but I haven't the desire or strength for an alternative.   Although English, I haven't joined the UK board, so didn't know about Tina - I'm really sorry it hit you so badly but it won't hurt to have a good weep.   Barbara x

Posts.Content: banjobanjo wrote: Just received a Facebook post from a friend. It was done using the 'pink ribbon app' and the message is 'We're all in this together'.  This made me angry because she's not 'in' anything except the vulnerability that comes with being female.  The only people I can accept are in this with me are the Stage IV women. This particular friend exhibits behaviour that I've noticed in a few others - she questions me and checks on my progress like she would check a barometer for the weather.  Thanks goodness she is in England and I am in Germany, which means I only have to be message-polite and not actually see her in person, so the danger of strangulation is fairly small. What I feel she is doing with her pink support and her pink fun runs is providing herself with a kind of personal insurance against getting breast cancer - the more she works for us, the less likely it is that she will be punished with cancer. In case any of you think I'm being too hard on her, I'll just say that I never found her much of a friend when she lived here and I was healthy, so nothing has changed.  Barbara 'And we are here as on a darkling plain, swept with confused alarms of struggle and flight, where ignorant armies clash by night. Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2011 09:36PM banjobanjo wrote: This will sound only mildly irritating compared with some of your stories but I am getting madder and madder each time it happens.  A member of my quilt group has not called or visited since my diagnosis, although some of the group pop in individually for quick visits (quick visits are always perfect) and always after texting me to see if I feel like a visit - normal contact, which makes me feel good.  This irritating woman, however, searches for soppy, new age, namby-pamby photos of forest glades, mountain tops, sunrises - each accompanied by preachy philosophical sayings - and she sends them to me in a slideshow.  Her accompanying message is always "Hello my dear Barbara, I am thinking of you all the time and have collected these photos to cheer you up and help you."  I could scream - every time the other quilt people visit, they all say how positive and cheerful I am and are 'amazed' at how I'm dealing with stuff - you know, the usual.  I assume that they share this with the members who don't visit.  So where does this woman get the idea that I'm depressed?  Where does she get this patronising attitude from that a few philosophical sayings will 'put me right' if I concentrate?  At first, I looked at them and emailed a quick thank you, then I didn't look and emailed thank you, now I just delete and don't answer.  I assume it makes her feel better, that she is being 'supportive', but in fact, it just shows she's terrified of cancer, doesn't want to come near me in case it is catching and really, she's the one who needs the philosophy... Thats-life - I'm half way through 'Emperor of Maladies' - heartbreaking, fascinating book. Barbara

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2012 03:42PM banjobanjo wrote: I agree.  I try not to go to my general practitioner any more because she thinks everything is probably cancer-related and therefore should go to my oncologist first.  So when I missed the bottom step of a flight of stairs three weeks ago in England and have been in various kinds of agony ever since. I waited to get back to Germany and went to my oncologist.  He sent me for x-rays, the radiologist said there were no fractures and he could see NO METASTASES.  I had already told him that my last spine MRI was stable and that this was an injury but he was concentrating on the cancer.  So I still don't know what I've done, can't get an appointment with an orthopaedic practice (health care is brilliant in Germany but you can wait a long time for orthopaedic care; they are so busy) and can't move on to neurologist until I've seen an orthopaedic doctor.  Still in pain, still eating painkillers and still no answers.  My right leg feels as though it belongs to somebody else and the pain has now gone right up my back to in between my shoulders - I'm fed up with hurting. Sorry everyone, part of my anger is sheer frustration that I did this to myself - if only we could turn back time.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 04:27AM - edited Nov 17, 2011 04:28AM by banjobanjo Thank goodness you arrived in time to revive him - he wasn't meant to die.  I can't begin to imagine how terrible this has been for you.  However, if  we want to look at the positive(!), at least it has triggered an opportunity for him to release all the stuff that he was bottling up - he now has medication and the chance to talk to a detached counsellor and he can say what he has up until now considered unsayable.  This is a good thing for both of you as he has been the manly support but he now has support as well and he obviously needs it.  Even Alpha males are weak when it comes to the person they love being sick - it is a big problem that they cannot actively solve and it must be so difficult to live with that powerlessness.  This is not going to get better quickly and you both have a lot of adjustment and talking to do.  I hope sincerely that over the next few weeks, your husband gets good professional care and that you recover from the shock of your experience. Very best wishes, and please let us know how you get on, Barbara

Posts.Content: banjobanjo wrote: Just wanted to say a quick thank you to all the people who responded when I first joined this group. Several of you said I should not be having the totally sleepless, black and fearful nights and that I should get some medication.  I simply hadn't thought of asking because I'd had such a heavy schedule of appointments, tests, op, daily treatments - it was a real treadmill.  However, my oncologist has now given me some Zopiclon and those magical little white darlings are giving me a six hour stretch of dreamless, perfect sleep every night.  I wake about 5.30 and then doze a bit but have a completely clear head and feel refreshed; in fact, better than I used to feel before I had cancer.  Because I've always had a dislike of any unnecessary medication, it never occurred to me to ask for tranquilisers but your advice was good - why worry about tranquilisers when I've got Stage IV cancer?   Thanks again, Barbara  Barbara 'And we are here as on a darkling plain, swept with confused alarms of struggle and flight, where ignorant armies clash by night. Posts.Content: banjobanjo wrote: I've been taking the odd Ibuprofen tablet when I've had back pain but it has increased this last week and on Sunday I needed something stronger.  I called the 24 hour doctor service at my onc. practice and he said I could double the ibuprofen but it wasn't the most suitable painkiller.  I said I could go to the emergency clinic and he thought that was a good idea.  Well, the doctor there gave me an injection of Trama and ten tablets (one morning, one evening).  All Sunday evening I had itchy skin like I'd been bitten. I woke on the Monday feeling bad and took the morning tablet. From then on I felt like I was dying - horrendously nauseous, not quite conscious, my head kept falling with my mouth open but I couldn't sleep, itchy skin, felt too awful.  I honestly thought this was the end and my husband just sat quietly in the corner of the bedroom because I couldn't bear to have anyone touch me.  Towards the early evening when the tablet started to wear off, I began to feel better but even Tuesday I felt wobbly even though I refused to take any more tablets. Later, we read up about this drug - apparently about half the people given it react in the way I did to some extent.  What kind of doctor would give such a strong drug to someone on chemo?  I just wanted something a bit stronger than Ibuprofen, not to be knocked out.  It frightened the hell out of me and I just wanted to warn anyone about the possible and quite common reaction that can happen.  I am sure it is a very effective painkiller for those who can tolerate it but be careful - you might not be able to. Going to see the oncologist on Friday about my spine to see if anything can be done. Barbara  Barbara 'And we are here as on a darkling plain, swept with confused alarms of struggle and flight, where ignorant armies clash by night. Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2012 02:11AM banjobanjo wrote: It's always much more hurtful when it's family who behave like this because, well, family should be close and united and supportive.  But they often aren't.  Maybe it's because they know they should be that the inadequate ones feel the pressure and stay away.  Friends are the same but we don't feel so bad about the 'missing' ones because we perhaps don't have the same expectations of them.  Although I live in Germany and my sister lives in England, we Skype often, she has come out for short stays and the cancer has added another level of bonding (there is an eight year age gap but we have always got on well).  Whereas my brother, five years younger than me, seems to have an odd problem; he's okay about talking on the phone (although won't initiate a call) but he will not Skype - my sister and I think he doesn't want to look at me but I look the same as I always did.  Weird. I think in the end we all know who can be relied upon to stick with us and they are the ones we should stick with.  I wouldn't waste any more time or energy on your 'lost' sister. Barbara

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2011 12:33PM banjobanjo wrote: Vicki, I'm sorry that your friends are becoming distant from you - some people just can't deal with a serious illness situation; they feel embarrassed, guilty, helpless, and although they probably don't consciously mean to, this ends up with them avoiding you because it means they don't have to confront their feelings too deeply. But you miss them, naturally.  I don't know if you would feel able to talk to them about the situation but sometimes I think open frankness can work very well.  If you could invite them round for coffee and cake and make a point of telling them that you miss them and feel that your illness is getting in the was of your friendships, it would get the subject into the open air and they could perhaps talk about how they might be nervous around you, don't know when to include you or not.  The outcome could be at least a regular get-together that doesn't include other people, just you and these friends.  I am sure they are still friends and still care for you - it's just that they don't have cancer.  But I bet they would respond if they knew you were hurting.  You have nothing to lose that you haven't already lost. Hope things improve (if not, how about joining a cancer support group - at least you would have each others' interests in common...) Sending good thoughts, Barbara x

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2012 06:33AM banjobanjo wrote: I still think that a wide variety of food gives the best diet.  Perhaps because each of us has a different DNA and a different cancer, foods/drinks have a different effect on us, so that green tea is good for one and bad for another.  The doctors can't tell us individually what will be best for our DNA and our tumour.  I avoid all extremes and eat/drink what I fancy in moderation.  This way, I get some of what is good for me and some of what may be bad for my particular situation but there is no real proof that can be generally applied and until there is, I am not going to fuss about my diet.  I never take sugar in drinks and don't drink fizzy drinks but I really enjoy good ice cream and cakes - that's where I choose to have my sugar.  I think balance is everything.

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2012 05:08PM banjobanjo wrote: I know that some people with cancer manage to be extremely active but for most of us Stage IVs life has narrowed to a certain extent.  I think of some elderly people who can only talk of what the neighbours are doing since their lives have become limited in experience and I think there is a touch of that about us.  When friends are being promoted, changing jobs, partners, doing lots of activities and vacations, we sometimes don't have a lot to entertain with in return as though cancer has made us stand still and life has gone on without us. I have two or three people who are very close friends and know everything about my diagnosis and treatment.  I have a small circle of good friends who know pretty much everything, although I have not told them about my brain mets yet, and they are a welcome embrace of normality who still see me as ME.  Outside that are the friendly acquaintances who I keep at a conversational distance in that I would rather hear about them than they hear about me.  I find most people love talking about themselves and what they've done and that if I say 'I'm fine' and then follow up with a question about their son/daughter/husband etc, they get distracted from me.  That's how I like it. What I do resent is that one friend I have known for 18 years had already drifted apart and it was quite a natural thing in that our children kept us in contact and are now grown and her interests and hobbies are very different to mine.  I accepted that we had naturally grown apart and I wasn't bothered.  However, when she heard from someone that I had cancer, she had a long telephone call with me and said she would visit.  I didn't hear any more for six months - then I got a call and she came round for coffee.  She stayed two hours and was very interested in my treatment and progress.  She entertained me with horseriding stories (she hunts and is training to do dressage) and I asked if I could come and see her compete.  She said she would call me to give me details of the next competition. That was months ago; I haven't heard from her since.  I feel I was some kind of interesting chemistry experiment - that she wanted to see what cancer had done to me but didn't want to have real contact.  I will probably hear from her if I'm alive in six months because she will want to observe the next stage.  Well, I'm a test tube that doesn't want to be observed so she'll get short shrift from me.

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2011 12:13PM banjobanjo wrote: Had my mastectomy and 16 lymph nodes about a month ago.  I did my exercises avidly in order to regain arm flexibility (helped, uncomfortably, by having to reach for handholds while having radiation to my spine - this pushed my flexibility more than I would have done voluntarily and has had a great effect).  As far as numbness from nerve damage, I've heard that you can help the nerves relearn their job and help them to regrow by gently stroking the areas with different textures to give them some stimulation.  I haven't actually tried this so have no idea if it works.  Instead, when my husband and I are sitting together on the sofa, he gently strokes my numb bits and I have noticed that there is a level of improvement.  It might have happened on its own but I really enjoy that little massage treatment so am giving my husband the credit! I do have a bit of swollen flesh under the armpit which remains hard and is a bit sore to lie on - no improvement in this and not sure what to do about it. Hope everyone gets their feeling back, Barbara

Posts.Content: banjobanjo wrote: Having finished six sessions of chemo, I had a meeting with my oncologist today.  He said I had got through the 'very aggressive' chemo and he wanted to give me a rest before starting new treatment.  So on 5th March (not much of a rest), I am to start on Zeloda but on a reduced dose (2000mg a day) because he thinks this will be effective enough without giving me side effects. I didn't get a lot of satisfaction out of the questions I took - isn't it weird that you think you are asking clear questions and you get answers to them but they are not really answers?  I went in thinking I was going on Herceptin and Tykerb, which is what he had mentioned in October but in November he got test results for me which said I was triple negative (previous test had said HER+), so I was feeling wrong-footed and taken aback and didn't know anything about Zeloda other than having heard the name on these boards. Now I see that Zeloda is usually taken in conjunction with another drug for most effective results and extended life - I am to take it on its own and don't know whether this means that the oncologist doesn't believe I am worth 'extending' or whether he believes that Zeloda alone will be effective enough. Radiation and chemo side effects have improved hugely the last few days and I am able to eat and actually enjoy food again so life is looking up.  I don't feel I have any real options other than to take the Zeloda and get on with it - going with the flow and hoping that it works out.  Barbara 'And we are here as on a darkling plain, swept with confused alarms of struggle and flight, where ignorant armies clash by night. Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2012 10:06AM banjobanjo wrote: Hi Jibb, welcome.  I too was diagnosed with spine and brain mets from first diagnosis.  My primary tumours were tiny, very aggressive and deep in the breast and the doctors wanted a mastectomy and lymph node removal immediately before any other treatment.  They feared that these tiny tumours would invade my lungs because they had sent cancer cells to spine and brain so quickly.  I was more than happy to have the mastectomy and did not find it at all traumatic.  I truly believe that, in my case, (I wouldn't dream of judging anyone else's) this operation extended the time I have.  I hope your doctors can make a good decision and can justify their decision to you sufficiently that you are happy to go along with it.  I'm also triple negative and this might have influenced their decision since there are fewer treatment options open to me. Barbara

Posts.Content: May 21, 2012 05:03PM banjobanjo wrote: Hi Laurie, I have been at the hospital most of today with my husband who was taken in as an emergency with a questionable stomach abscess/inflamed hernia - they have operated this evening but could not give me any information other than that he was back in his room and asleep.  I need to visit early in the morning to find out what they found and what they did. Consequently, I haven't been here to find out your results.  I am so sad that it wasn't migraines, which we all hoped it was.  When I was diagnosed, I thought I only had spinal mets because the doctor held back on the brain mets info until I'd had my mastectomy and he thought I could take more bad news - in fact, let's face it, the worst kind of news.  I'd got through the op easily and was dealing with the idea of a damaged spine and hoping they could repair it in some way and was positive.  Then brain mets seemed the death blow.  I wondered why they had bothered doing a mastectomy if I had brain mets because of course I would die very soon.  But the doctors thought I was worth investing in and the brain mets were just something else for them to treat.  My oncologist always says that I am not in a war against cancer but a series of separate battles fought on different fronts. In fact the WBR I had worked well and has given me more time.  Brain mets, although a terrible idea, end up being something else on the list of what we need to accept.  I remember my shock, my feeling of dread at losing my mind, my personality, etc.  But in the end I just got up in the morning and went to bed at night and realised that I wasn't going to die yet.  You're like all of us, alternately strong and wobbly, but when they decide how they are going to treat you, you will start to deal with it.  Please don't give up.  Barbara x

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2012 05:36PM banjobanjo wrote: Elizabeth, don't be fooled; we are all afraid all of the time but feeling the fear directly is very tiring and so we supress it, put it in a box and just lift the lid and take a peek mostly.  I look at other people exactly the same as you do, thinking how free from care they are, how carelessly they plan for the future with no thought that it might not be there.  I look at people frowning and scornfully wonder what they can possible have to worry about compared to cancer.  But my friends see me as incredibly positive and strong in the way I'm dealing with it - that's the persona I show them.  In a way, acting positive brings about a real positivity; it may be superficial but it makes everything so much easier.  Mind you, when I was suffering from the first aggressive chemo I had, I was so sick and afraid that I couldn't see ahead at all.  But, like so many people have said on different threads, we have to move forward and we should make it as pleasant for ourselves as possible because the alternative is horrible. Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2012 02:39AM - edited Jul 14, 2012 02:42AM by banjobanjo The problem is that 'alternative' covers a large range from acceptable complementary treatment to downright weird suggestions with miracle results - you have to draw your own line where one stops and the other begins. It seems clear to me that if anyone claims that an alternative treatment (however weird) has the ability to cure cancer, then they should be happy to undergo clinical trials, tests and have at the end scientifically acceptable proof of their claim.  Instead, most of these suggestions are preying on people who are full of fear, some of whom want to believe so badly that they will try anything.  I can go with chemo because although it will not cure us, there is scientific evidence that in most cases it has a life-extending effect.  When I have scientific proof that an alternative treatment has a life-extending effect, then I will be prepared to try it but most of the people promoting such things flee at the first sign of investigation. My other point is that physicians have a goal which is to heal and I do not support the 'conspiracy against a cure' theory. If they had good reason to believe in a specific alternative treatment, they would use it but only if trialled and proven.  They want us to get better if only they knew how.  I am very sad about my diagnosis but am not gullible enough to give money to someone who is exploiting my sadness.  Of course, we should eat as healthily as we can, but then so should everyone...

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2012 02:49AM banjobanjo wrote: We are all wimps sometimes, all have wimpish episodes, but none of us are cowards and if you look back on all you have been through in your treatments, you will realise how persistently brave you have been to get through this far. It seems there are two problems - firstly, you have had enough suffering from side effects of chemos and secondly, you don't feel these chemos are working, which makes the suffering not worthwhile.  I don't know how many other chemo options are out there for you, but I suspect that if they changed your treatment and could find an alternative that was gentler on you (or they could combat the side effects with other drugs), then you would probably pick up again and see the point of carrying on.  Physically feeling rotten is psychologically very wearing -  I remember my first aggressive chemo course and lying on the sofa thinking I would never be well again and what was the point of feeling so awful all the time?  Of course, as soon as things got better I became more positive but at the time I was ready to give up and I had only just started.  It must be much worse for you as you have had bad side effects for a long time - I admire your endurance. I hope a talk with your oncologist will communicate how bad you are feeling and prompt him/her to explore any treatments which you haven't tried yet and wish you the very best of luck. Barbara

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 01:41AM banjobanjo wrote: Hi Michelle, Sorry that you need to come here but welcome.  I think the key word is gradually.  Gradual acceptance of what is. Then move on to what can be, not what can't be. I'm a similar age, 59 (for a few more weeks...), and I understand the grandchildren thing; don't expect I'll be here to see any.  In fact, my youngest daughter has said she doesn't think she wants children and I'm wondering if this is true or if she's just saying it to make me feel better.  But there is so much other stuff to look forward to and I don't mean a bucket list of events.  I mean just the months, possibly years ahead that we get to enjoy our families, friends, nature, our homes.  I don't want to do anything or go anywhere exciting - I just want an everyday life and to feel well as long as I can.   Don't want any of the above to sound preachy but I remember the panic I was in when diagnosed and I got through it by acceptance and adjustment but it took quite a while and I didn't think I could carry on but 'take one day at a time' seems to be the best advice I had. There's always someone here not only to listen but also, amongst this group, you will find all sorts of advice from women who have been here a while.  So let us know how you are doing, you are one of us.

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2011 12:49PM banjobanjo wrote: Hi Susandot, I'm sorry to hear about your mother but can't give advice because I am pretty much at the same stage, except that I have been doing chemo at the same time as the RT.  I finished 21 treatments of WBR two weeks ago and have also had my steroids gradually reduced (thank goodness) until I am now only taking a quarter of a tablet (1mg) each morning and next week - NONE!  My muscle tone in my legs is poor and I am trying to do at least two walks a day, gently with the dog and my husband, to start the process of strengthening everything for when the steroids are completely gone.  I felt fine all through the RT - only had some side effects since it stopped - fatigue, loss of hearing, slightly forgetful (although I always have been a bit) and some muscle spasms in my neck if I move it quickly.  They are not planning to scan until at least eight weeks after I finished because I also had RT on my spine and that takes eight weeks to go on working so they want those effects to be finished before they scan.  I believe the WBR goes on working after the treatments stop as well and maybe that is why your mother is feeling a bit dizzy?   The only advice I would give is that you/and your mother should call the radiologist who did the WBR and ask your questions - apparently WBR side effects can last months and if they explain this to your mother, she won't worry so much about her brain, I hope. Good luck, let us know how you get on, Barbara
